The price of any cost type (hour, expense, or fee) that is assigned to a specific group of customers or all customers.

A type of user account that allows complete access to the computer. Administrators can make any desired changes. This account type is not recommended for daily use, and should only be used when necessary.
An option on a user account setup dialog that creates an administrator account.
The windowing and graphics subsystem that supports windows and user interface controls.
To continue a process or service that has been paused.
To set an entity, such as a feature, configuration, or object, back to its defaults.
A unique alphanumeric name used to identify a department.
A financial account that tracks assets, liabilities, revenue, or expenses.
The governmental agency that taxes are paid to.

In Active Directory, a collection of computer, user, and group objects defined by the administrator. These objects share a common directory database, security policies, and security relationships with other domains.
In DNS, any tree or subtree within the DNS namespace.
A navigation button used to complete and close a wizard.
A named group of accounts or dimensions that contains either account values for the account or dimension values for a single dimension.
The code that represents the cause for a certain action.
A code that represents the physical location where an employee works in the organization.
The expected total cost of a task or project, based on performance as of the status date. EAC is calculated as follows: EAC = ACWP + (BAC-BCWP)/CPI.
To briefly press a UI element with your fingertip or stylus to perform an activity (such as choosing an action from a menu or opening an item).

A code that credit card companies use to authorize credit card charges. For example, American Express uses a four-digit number on the front of the credit card, and Visa, MasterCard, and Discover use a three-digit number on the back.

A code that credit card companies use to authorize credit card charges. For example, American Express uses a four-digit number on the front of the credit card, and Visa, MasterCard, and Discover use a three-digit number on the back.

A code that credit card companies use to authorize credit card charges. For example, American Express uses a four-digit number on the front of the credit card, and Visa, MasterCard, and Discover use a three-digit number on the back.

A code that credit card companies use to authorize credit card charges. For example, American Express uses a four-digit number on the front of the credit card, and Visa, MasterCard, and Discover use a three-digit number on the back.
A notification that is displayed to a user when user-defined criteria are met.
Software that enables parents and guardians to customize children's web experiences in order to help protect their safety and privacy online.
Software that enables parents and guardians to customize children's web experiences in order to help protect their safety and privacy online.
A list of people, invited by the user, that includes the display picture, notes, and tags for each friend.
The folder that by default receives new messages.
A tool that enables a user to get another user's attention by shaking the user's conversation window and playing a sound.
An animated greeting a customer can send to a contact.
The color or image that appears behind the content of a visual element, for example, behind the text that is displayed in a TextBox control or on your graphical user interface.
A display mode that shows as much content as possible by hiding elements such as navigation and toolbars.
A storage unit directly connected to the network using standard protocols such as Ethernet and TCP/IP for providing file access services.
To change the modality of a conversation from, say, voice call to video, starting from a pop-up notification.
The microphone and speaker on a calling device/phone that allows you to converse with someone without using the handset or headset.
A current attempt by a second party to establish communication with a user.
To take action to not answer a call. The call goes to voice mail if that service is available.
The person who is calling another person or place.
To accept an incoming telephone call.
A picture made by combining a series of photos into one large picture to provide a complete view of an area or location that cannot fit in a single shot.
The image or avatar someone adds to their profile to represent themselves.
A collection of communications (e-mail, IM, text messaging, voice mail, and so on) between two or more participants.
A short alphanumeric message that is sent between mobile phones or devices using the SMS protocol.
A short alphanumeric message that is sent between mobile phones or devices using the SMS protocol.
A short alphanumeric message that is sent between mobile phones or devices using the SMS protocol.

Private information that a customer provides to establish their Windows Live ID. This information is separate from the customer's (outward-facing) profile and is never shared without explicit consent.
A policy that specifies the length of time during which data, documents, and other records must be available for recovery.
A communication technology based on short range (4cm or less) wireless data exchange.
A communication technology based on short range (4cm or less) wireless data exchange.

A piece or slice of a Web page that users can directly subscribe to from the browser. The browser checks if the piece of the web has updates, and indicates to the user when there are new updates available. Users can preview the piece of the Web before navigating to the full Web page.
A feature of Hyper-V that allows a running virtual machine to be managed remotely through an interactive session.
The window that displays solutions, projects, and files, as well as access to the commands that pertain to them.
The information provided with a product by a manufacturer describing how to use a product.
An Internet domain name that can accommodate non-ASCII characters such as the diacritical marks of European language or non-Latinate characters such as those found in Chinese, Korean or Arabic.

A type of user account that prohibits users from changing most computer settings and deleting important files. While such a user can access applications, they generally cannot install software or hardware, among other things.
A tool that automates the running of application installations while monitoring the actions taken by each application's installer.
A Windows serviceability tool used to help prioritize the testing of applications when evaluating a new Windows update.
To tap a device screen and hold one's finger or stylus in place.
To tap a device screen and hold one's finger or stylus in place.
A telephone message delivered to a voicemail system.
A program that extends the capabilities of Internet Explorer.
A list or outline of things to be done or considered.
A card, inserted into a portable device, used to store files.

An instruction that tells Windows Firewall to open a port briefly, allow a program or service to pass a specific piece of information through, and then close the port. These instructions are called "exceptions" because normally the firewall blocks all unsolicited attempts to send information.

To display files that meet certain criteria. For example, you might filter files by a particular author so that you only see the files written by that person. Filtering does not delete files, it simply changes the view so that you only see the files that meet your criteria.

A collection of visual elements and sounds for your computer desktop or device User Interface. A theme determines the look of the various visual elements of your User Interface, such as windows, icons, fonts, and colors, and it can include sounds.

An Internet Explorer feature that allows users to surf the Web without leaving a browsing history, cookies or other information on the PC so they can do online banking on a shared computer, for example.
An intelligent spam-filtering solution integrated across all Microsoft e-mail platforms.
A service for wireless products that allows users to send and receive brief messages consisting of text and numbers to and from mobile phones and devices.
A custom grouping used to organize your data and to create customized reports.

A virtual community that provides people with opportunities to interact (via blogs, chats, newsgroups, webcasts, user groups, and forums) with Microsoft employees, experts, and peers in order to share knowledge and news about Microsoft technology.
The sound made by a mobile device or other phone to indicate an incoming call or message, for example, a series of beeps or an audio recording.
An alert that is set by the user to be activated at a particular time.
A deployment method that requires minimal interaction with the user.
The ISO standard notation for independent specification of data types and structures for syntax conversion.

A folder that provides you with a convenient place to store documents, e.g. text files, spreadsheets, and presentations, or other files you want to access quickly. When you save a file in a program such as WordPad, the file is automatically saved in Documents, unless you choose a different folder.
A folder that stores the user's graphics, e.g. digital pictures. Many graphic design and photo-editing programs use this location by default to open or save graphic files.

To add a new calendar in the iCalendar format (.ics) to Windows Calendar and receive updates. For example, you can subscribe to a calendar on a server or to Internet calendars from major sports teams, television and radio shows, academic institutions, etc.

A series of digital-media files that users can subscribe to online, that are sent to their computers and that can then be accessed on demand on the users' reader. The majority of podcasts are available as audio files in MP3 format, syndicated through an RSS (XML) file. Other formats and other types of files, such as video, can also be podcasted.
To monitor an e-mail conversation or newsgroup thread. The headers for messages in a watched conversation appear in a different color, which makes them easier to find in a message list.

An option on the Views menu in Windows Explorer that shows the most appropriate details for the file type in a flexible layout rather than only showing the details associated with the column headers in the view.

A comprehensive PC maintenance center that provides the user with a single point of entry for tasks and notifications associated with PC Health, i.e. security, diagnostics, problem reports and solutions, how to update the system (Windows Updates), performance, reliability, backup and restore, and complete PC backup (recovery and Rescue my PC).
A group of computers on a home network that can share pictures, music, videos, documents, and printers. A homegroup is created by using the HomeGroup feature; it is protected with a password.
An instant message session with multiple parties, exchanged via IM (not through your mobile operator).
The software that is running within a virtual machine (i.e., guest operating systems and guest applications).
A collection of items, such as files and folders, assembled from various locations. The locations might be on your computer, an external hard drive, removable media, or someone elseâ€™s computer.
To fix an item, such as a tile, library, movie, game, or app, in a given area of the UI, so it is always accessible in that area (e.g., to make a library always visible in the navigation pane).
To remove an item, such as a tile, library, movie, game, or app, from a given area of the UI, to make it inaccessible in that area (e.g. to make a library non-visible in the navigation pane).
A person who manages accounts and determines safety settings.
A Windows Live account that manages a subscription.
To locate or come upon through action.
To create a sound, vibration, visual cue, or any other indication that the user has an incoming call.
A feature in Internet Explorer that helps detect phishing websites and can help protect you from installing malicious software or malware.

A type of browser extension that gives users quick access to their Web and client applications from any Web page. An Accelerator can run on user-selected data, links, and the current document. This browser extension can provide â€œlookupâ€ service like in-place definition or â€œsendâ€ service like sending selected text to a Web e-mail provider.

A radio navigation system developed by the U.S. Department of Defense that uses a constellation of 24 earth satellites, which are monitored by ground-based control stations, to provide precise, continuous worldwide positioning and timing information.
The process of maintaining connectivity outside of one's usual service or coverage area.
A connection that enables the transmission of data.
A call that originates from your mobile device.
A collaborative action, such as sharing, calendar sharing, or using a whiteboard.
An item on the user's Status menu. A user can select this status to indicate that they are not actively using their computer.
E-mail that a customer does not want delivered to their inbox, including spam and phishing messages (identified by the mail service) and messages from blocked senders and domains.
The part of a sales order that specifies the detailed information about a requested item.

A set of colors and background images that lets users change the appearance of Windows Live pages. The theme is common to all pages, except for group, event, and space pages, which may each have their own theme.
To copy something from a computer to a location online, such as a photo album or a blog post.
Parental consent for a child to use a Windows Live service, view a website, or communicate with a person.
A content element a user can add to their space.
The overall design of a page or content set, including text elements, controls, and graphics.

A post, comments, and responses made within a conversation space, such as a message board, help board, community, newsgroup, or blog. These exchanges are usually publicly viewable. Participation may require credentials, such as a Windows Live ID.

The descriptive information about a user that is shown to other users. This editable information is separate from the registration information they provide to establish their Windows Live account. This separation allows users to disclose or conceal personal information as they choose.
An answer that only the user knows for a specific question. The answer is used to confirm someone's identity if they forget their password.

A security type that helps prevent unauthorized persons from discerning that a user is going to the Windows Live sign-in page. Otherwise, an unauthorized person might be able to intercept and manipulate the code on the sign-in page, which could result in user information being transmitted to an unauthorized website.
A menu item that enables users to initiate operations, such as sending an instant message or playing a game.

A horizontal grouping of actions that apply to the container (or containers) with which the toolbar is associated. For example, a container in which mail is viewed might have an action toolbar with options that include Reply, Delete, and Move to.
A recognition feature that helps increase input speed and reduce effort by providing users with word completion and next word prediction alternates as the user is writing/typing.
A multi-touch gesture that consists of one or two fingers moving in the same direction, parallel to each other.
A multi-touch gesture that consists of two fingers moving in opposite directions (-> <- or <- ->).
The worldwide collection of networks and gateways that use the TCP/IP suite of protocols to communicate with one another.
The worldwide collection of networks and gateways that use the TCP/IP suite of protocols to communicate with one another.

The entity that offers a remote workspace, typically the IT department of the userâ€™s employer, a business partner or vendor, or less commonly, a commercial application service provider. The publisher may use a digital certificate to represent its identity and use it to sign the remote resource files (e.g. RDP files) and the workspace description (e.g. Web Service feed).
To make an object, such as a file, accessible.
The process of adding geospatial metadata (e.g. longitude, latitude) to media (e.g. Websites, RSS feeds, or images).
A mode of Windows Photo Viewer which consists of a top level window displaying one photograph at a time, with navigation controls.

To remove data permanently from a storage medium. This is usually done by replacing existing data with zeros or meaningless text or, in magnetic media, by disturbing the magnetic particles' physical arrangement, either with the erase head or with a large magnet.
A note that contains recorded information.
To establish a Bluetooth link or connection between two Bluetoothâ€“enabled devices.
To make a single file out of a set of files using a program such as compress, gzip, or PKZIP.
A radio network that provides coverage for cellular telephone communications.
A Windows feature that enables users to share pictures, music, videos, documents, and printers with other people on a home network.
A personal web presence provided by the Windows Live Spaces service.
A personal web presence provided by the Windows Live Spaces service.
A list of messages that you have sent or received.
A list that displays someone's recent activity on Windows Live.
The contact picture label that indicates someone has been invited to do something, but has not responded yet.
The link to the webpage where a user manages photos and albums.
The link to the main landing/start page on Windows Live.
The use of Web sites and services that provide enhanced information and interaction capabilities with regard to people and resources.
An extensible platform component for decoding/encoding digital images and performing common transforms.
A Windows feature that provides a direct connection to a corporate network for people working outside of the office. It is a superior alternative to VPN.
A PC (desktop and beyond) search platform that allows search of the local hard drive plus network locations like SharePoint sites and the Internet.
A set of attributes that define a user's access to a given service or application.
To break a connection.
To call the last person called from a phone or device.
To send text messages from a mobile phone or device.
To reject or turn off a system notification such as a reminder, a new message alert or an alarm.
A telephone call the user has failed to answer.
As set of rules defined by the administrator. For example, the policy may require all users to change their passwords.
A company that provides services or content for its customers.
A Windows Phone application that is both a digital still camera and a digital video camera.
An occurrence, activity or happening of significance that occurs.
The on-screen representation of the phone keypad or dial pad on the device.
The mechanical part that makes the phone ring to indicate an incoming call.
A type of personal identification number (PIN) for the SIM card, consisting of 4 digits, that is used to gain access to your mobile phone.
To expose a virtual disk to the user, backed by a file.

The administrative task of making remote resources available to its users, setting policies that control how users will connect, how they will find the remote resources, and what settings users will connect with.
A piece of software handling application-related data consistency during backup and restore operations.
To remove a Bluetooth link or connection between two Bluetoothâ€“enabled devices.
A view mode in Internet Explorer that determines whether content is rendered as if users were viewing it in a previous version of Internet Explorer.
An Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE) 802.11 wireless network in which Service Set Identifier (SSID) suppression is enabled.

A feature that prevents Internet Explorer from storing data about your browsing session. This helps prevent anyone else who might be using your computer from seeing where you visited and what you looked at on the Web.
The feature that blocks third-party web content that could potentially track someone's web activity.
The link group that includes links to the About Hotmail webpage, the What's New webpage, and so on.
The Windows Live webpage that displays security and safety-related activities.

The link that appears above an incomplete content set and leads to the full list of items. For example, when a content module displays items 1â€“6, a "View all" link in line with the module label leads to a webpage that lists all items. The items that are available in preview are redundantly available in the list of all items, which may be paginated.
The image that appears in the conversation window.
A contribution or feedback left by someone viewing content on a site. Someone who views a space, photos, or files can leave a comment, if permissions allow it.
A wizard that helps you set up an Internet connection.
To group together multiple windows of the same application under a single button on the taskbarâ€™s taskband.
A zoom out gesture represented by two fingers with at least one of them moving towards the other finger at any angle, within an acceptable tolerance.
A zoom-in gesture represented by two fingers with at least one of them moving away from each other at any angle, within an acceptable tolerance.
A zoom-in gesture represented by two fingers with at least one of them moving away from each other at any angle, within an acceptable tolerance.
A node that makes cached data available to clients needing to retrieve the data.
To apply a marker to content or items (like photos or text) to identify certain types of information.
The process of assigning initial values to variables and data structures in a program.

A COM-based multimedia platform and infrastructure for digital media in Microsoft Windows. It focuses on content protection, audio and video quality, and interoperability for digital rights management (DRM).

A COM-based multimedia platform and infrastructure for digital media in Microsoft Windows. It focuses on content protection, audio and video quality, and interoperability for digital rights management (DRM).
The process of testing whether two data items are identical or of finding a data item that is identical to a key.
A method of blocking access to websites based on their content. For example, In Windows Live Family Safety, parents can specify a filtering level, such as Strict or Basic, for their child.
A Web site from Microsoft which provides solutions for the top issues about Windows Update or Microsoft Update, and enables you to contact a support professional.
A device that receives digital audio wirelessly from your computer and broadcasts it to TV sets or stereos around your home.

A sub-feature of Application Telemetry whose goal is to gather information on how applications use features exposed by the operating system (COM objects, registry, DLLs, DLL exports, etc.). This data is used to better understand how a change to or removal of a Windows feature may impact applications and overall application compatibility goals. It also helps understand how features are used, and allows Microsoft to use that information in planning new features, allocating testing resources, etc.

A powerful inventory, assessment, and reporting tool that can run securely in small or large IT environments without requiring the installation of agent software on any computers or devices. The data and analysis provided by this toolkit can significantly simplify the planning process for migrating to Windows.
A computer connected to a local computer though either inbound connections or outbound connections.
To gain access to all phone functionality by entering the correct password when the phone has locked itself due to delayed use or when the user has manually locked it.
A numeric keypad that is part of a device, is displayed on a device, or is in a computer program that you use to enter information in the context of a phone call.

A group of people someone communicates and shares with on Windows Live. Someone's network includes people they've added to their profile, to their Messenger contacts, or both. People in someone's network can see information about their latest activities in the what's new list, and may see other information, depending on permissions settings.
To permit someone else to perform an action. For example, to let someone else see your online status, send you messages, or see your public Messenger information.
A navigation button used to return to recently visited Web pages in Internet Explorer and other internet browsers.
Intel's implementation of simultaneous multithreading that allows a single physical processor to execute multiple threads (instruction streams) simultaneously.

Permissions to use a protected Windows Media-based file in a particular way. For example, a content provider, such as an online music store, can grant you the right to play a song on your computer (a play right), to burn the song to an audio CD (a burn right), or to sync the song to a portable device (a sync right). The content provider dictates the terms of the rights (for example, which rights it grants to you and for how long) and Windows Media Digital Rights Management(DRM) enforces those rights.
A small, affordable laptop that is designed to perform a limited number of tasks such as web browsing and e-mail.

A technique for adding memory to PCs that allows for increasing memory beyond the Intel 80x86 microprocessor real-mode limit of 1 megabyte (MB). In earlier versions of microprocessors, EMS bypassed this memory board limit with a number of 16-kilobyte banks of RAM that could be accessed by software. In later versions of Intel microprocessors, including the 80386 and 80486 models, EMS is converted from extended memory by software memory managers, such as EMM386 in MS-DOS 5. Now EMS is used mainly for older MS-DOS applications because Windows and other applications running in protected mode on 80386 and higher microprocessors are free of the 1-MB limit.
A place with an address (not necessarily physical), such as your home, your workplace, or your dial-up Internet connection location.
The heading for information about the time at which something was added, changed, or re-posted.
The title of the window in which the Windows Live Messenger Today page is displayed.
A map view created from aerial photos that shows buildings, roads, and geographical features.

A set of guidelines released by the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) in May 1999. The WAI is intended to promote Web accessibility for users with disabilities by setting Web design and compatibility guidelines that help assure Web access and usability for all users.
The combination of hardware (touchscreen or touchpad) and software elements that provides a way to control programs by touching multiple points on the screen simultaneously.
A predefined collection of audio files (for example, songs) from a CD or digital download.
The street address or geographical coordinates of a user, and (by way of extensions) of the userâ€™s computer or devices.
A character used in synchronous (timed) communications that enables the sending and receiving devices to maintain the same timing.
A question, usually from a drop-down list, that users can use to confirm their identity and reset their password in case they have forgotten it.
A tag used to identify a person in a photo.

The heading for the tags that identify people in a photo. This heading is used for the group of all people tags used in someone's photo gallery, and for the group of people tags in an individual photo.
The feature that allows users to stream music, images or videos to a specific device on their home network.
To enter information by means of the keyboard or other input method.

In computer systems, a reduction in level of performance or service. Degradation in microcomputer performance is indicated by slow response times or frequent pauses for disk access because memory is insufficient to hold an entire program plus the data the program is using.
A small, often removable chip on a larger data card that stores identity and security information for mobile broadband and other cellular services.
In Internet Backgammon, one of the twenty-four narrow triangles (twelve on each side) that make up the board.
A standard control that resembles a notebook and lets the user navigate different sections of information without leaving the current element on the screen.
The ability to view data or navigate to or within a physical or virtual computer environment.
An account holder who is a family member, but not a parent, and who has limited use of the Internet. Children can view their own settings, but they can't change them.
An account holder who is a parent or a child.
An account holder who is the primary administrator (parent) and the family members they manage.
To join or combine thereby increasing the quantity or size of something.
To adjust the action or aspects of a group of items, typically done more than once.
In Internet Backgammon, the middle ridge that separates the two sides of the board.
A "device," recognized by the operating system, that can be addressed like a physical output device (such as a printer) but that discards any information sent to it.

A â€œsoftware-plus-servicesâ€ platform and experience that enables PCs and other devices to â€œcome aliveâ€ by making them aware of each other through the Internet, enabling individuals and organizations to manage, access, and share their files and applications seamlessly on the Web and across their world of devices.
A regular, rapidly recurring signal emitted by a clocking circuit.
A UI or media segment that can display on top of or play concurrently with another UI or media segment.
To return to a stable condition after some error has occurred. A program recovers from an error by stabilizing itself and resuming execution of instructions without user intervention.
The time during which a program is running. In most interactive programs, a session is the time during which the program accepts input and processes information.
A report that an administrator, parent, or guardian can view showing children's or family members' online activity.
The link to the form where a user can report violations of the terms of use. Contextually, it's understood that the abuse in question is poor conduct, such as obscene language or threats.
Rules that explain how someone should behave while using a service or product.
An installation package that the user downloads from http://download.live.com/?mkt=en-us.
A user-defined and annotated group of points of interest. Users can create collections for their own use or make them searchable for use by other users.
The button next to a search box that someone clicks to search for something.
In programming, to put something into code, which frequently involves changing the form: for example, changing a decimal number to binary-coded form.
The most recent or current version of a software release.
The status menu item that makes it appear to the userâ€™s contacts that he or she is currently offline.
A process that restricts the flow of data.
In MS-DOS, the file name extension of a file that is an executable program. To run an executable program, the user types the filename without the .exe extension at the prompt and presses Enter.
The file name extension of GIF bit map image files.
A telecommunications standard that lets users send and receive messages that include rich text, images, audio, and video.
A desktop app that enables WYSIWYG editing, offline editing, and preview functionality.
A desktop app that enables WYSIWYG editing, offline editing, and preview functionality.

The Windows Live service that enables a user to create a personal website where they can create and update a blog, and share their photos, music playlists and more, to connect with friends, family, or the online world.
The Microsoft online service that lets users access and share documents, photos, and other files from anywhere.
The Microsoft online service that lets users access and share documents, photos, and other files from anywhere.
A desktop app that enables users to view, manage, edit, and share photos and videos.
A desktop app that enables users to view, manage, edit, and share photos and videos.

An instant messaging and video chat service designed for a consumer audience (not for the enterprise). Messenger is available via a desktop app, on the web (no installation needed), and on mobile devices.

An instant messaging and video chat service designed for a consumer audience (not for the enterprise). Messenger is available via a desktop app, on the web (no installation needed), and on mobile devices.
The desktop e-mail program that lets users manage multiple e-mail accounts, newsgroups, and feeds in one place.
A quick, straight stroke of a finger or pen on a screen. A flick is recognized as a gesture, and interpreted as a navigation or an editing command.
A task page in the Windows Control Panel from where customers can get real-time status information about their network, and also make changes to settings.

An area in a window in which commands and other controls are displayed in functionally related groups. A ribbon can be divided into multiple views, known as tabs, and every tab can contain multiple groups of controls. Typically, a ribbon appears at the top of a window.
The web email service for domains supported by Microsoft account, including @hotmail.com and @live.com.
The web email service for domains supported by Microsoft account, including @hotmail.com and @live.com.
The set of Microsoft software for email, instant messaging, photos, and personal movies available to customers in a single download and installation.

The Windows Live universal roaming contact list that allows users to share their contact information and subscribe to othersâ€™ to automatically receive updates across Windows Live Messenger and Windows Live Spaces.
The Windows Live service that lets people and groups add, manage, and share event information.
The category of services that includes OneDrive, Outlook.com, and Skype.

A protocol used for synchronizing the system time on a computer to that of a server or other reference source such as a radio, satellite receiver, or modem. NTP provides time accuracy within a millisecond on local area networks and a few tens of milliseconds on wide area networks. NTP configurations may utilize redundant servers, diverse network paths, and cryptographic authentication to achieve high accuracy and reliability.
The Microsoft service that facilitates web searches.
One of the interchange points for Internet traffic, where various Internet network carriers and major ISPs exchange data.
To set again with a different value.
To obtain a new password when the old one is forgotten or expired. As opposed to changing a password, when a password is reset, the user does not get to choose the new password.

A feature that uses speech recognition to enable you to interact with your computer or other devices by voice. You can dictate documents and e-mails in mainstream applications, and use voice commands to start and switch between applications, control the operating system and even fill out forms on the web.
A text-based post on Twitter.
A text-based post on Twitter.
The Bing service that allows search and view of maps and satellite images.
The Bing service that allows search and view of maps and satellite images.
The phone number for a mobile phone.
Descriptive text that represents the audio content of a television or video program as text on the screen. Captions are usually visible only if decoded or activated.
Descriptive text that represents the audio content of a television or video program as text on the screen. Captions are usually visible only if decoded or activated.
To send an instant message.
A serial communications pathway built into Apple Macintosh and Apple IIGS computers.
A special-purpose terminal that bank customers can use to make deposits, obtain cash, and perform other transactions.
An online process that confirms whether installed software was properly activated.
To use an online process to confirm whether installed software was properly activated.
The link to the Microsoft service agreement.
The link to the personal page where users can store information (such as personal interests) and links (such as to friends and photos).
The link to the list of contacts from your mail and messenger accounts.
The link to Windows Live Hotmail.
The link to the list of more links to other Microsoft sites.
The link to the online calendar on Windows Live Calendar.
The link to the online shared event organiser on Windows Live Events.
The link to the online communities on Windows Live Groups.
The link to the user's personal online space, with blog functionality, photo albums, and lists, on Windows Live Spaces.
The link to the site to manage online access rights for, and monitor internet usage of, family members on Windows Live Family Safety.
The link to the site to manage online access rights for, and monitor internet usage of, family members on Windows Live Family Safety.
The link to the Windows Live site where users can register their mobile phone and find information about the Windows Live for Mobile services.
The link to the site to download client versions of Windows Live products such as Windows Live Mail, Windows Live Messenger, etc.
The link to the page where users enter information for the methods by which they can be contacted, such as Messenger, home phone, mobile phone, and e-mail.
A device that runs Windows Phone Operating System.
The link to the free online workspace for accessing, editing, and sharing Excel, Word, PowerPoint and OneNote documents across your PC, smartphone, and web browser.
The link to bing.com in some regions but to a dropdown list of more Bing options in other regions.
The link to the website where customers add computers (both PCs and Macs), mobile phones, and digital photo frames so they can access their synced folders and connect remotely to their devices.
The link to the code of conduct, which contains rules that explain how someone should behave while using a service or product.
The link to photos that only you and people that you select can view (versus public photos that anyone can view).
The link to the Microsoft service agreement.
A network made of people or organizations linked by some type of social relationship.

A domain that is engaged in a trust relationship with another domain, which is also called a federation. This relationship is between two federation servers, and allows a system to provide controlled access to its resources or services to a user that belongs to another security realm without requiring the user to authenticate directly to the system and without the two systems sharing a database of user identities or passwords.
A feature in Internet Explorer that restores data when a tab crashes in a session; if the whole window crashes, data is deleted and the window cannot be restored.
A power mode indicating that the device is always on.

A type of Human Interaction Proof challenge, which plays an audio file decipherable only by a person. The audio file might seem faint or mixed with background voices and noise. This is intentional to ensure a person, not an automated program, completes the HIP challenge.
One of the seven days of a week, the first day being a Sunday for U.S. English.
An instance that begins when someone signs into a web service or program.
The display name UI label used when there isnâ€™t a display name value available, as when data can't be retrieved or someone hasnâ€™t completely filled out their profile.
The label for the Windows Live Devices task webpage where someone specifies a name and an icon for the computer that they plan to sync.
The UI label for the Hotmail quick view that displays only the e-mail messages that originate from a social networking service such as Facebook.
The webpage subheading for the view in Messenger that displays the social activity of friends.
The webpage subheading for the list of synced folders.

The UI label for the social activity stream that Windows Live programmatically displays in a collection. Items listed may originate within a Windows Live program, service, or landing page (Messenger, OneDrive, Windows Live Photos), or in third-party activities people connect to their profiles, such as Facebook.
To add a personal touch to something.

A view that provides one-click access to a subset of e-mail messages based on specific criteria, which include: flagged (messages that the customer has designated as requiring follow-up), photos (messages that contain photos), and social updates (messages that originate from a social networking service such as Facebook).
The webpage subheading for the view in Messenger that displays someone's friends and contacts that aren't friends but that can be interacted with in Messenger (those are often legacy entries).
An application that is meant to run on a desktop computer.
A small icon, image or title that is associated with a user's name and that provides a visual indication of their role, contribution level, or other achievement or affiliation.
Entities that describe the parties, locations, products, and activities that are referenced by entities that document and record economic, resource flow, and accounting events.

To remove the ability of a network object, such as a user account or a network-joined computer to access the resources that the server provides. Deactivating a network object does not delete the object from the active directory, nor does it delete any data that is associated with the object.
A person someone has established a mutual connection with. The connection could have been made on Windows Live or in any connected social networking service.
The UI label in Messenger for the results list of a contacts search.
The UI label for a permissions setting that indicates an item is being shared with (made available to) all of someone's friends.
A module someone can add to their Windows Live Space to contain personal interest items such as music, books, and movies.
A module in Spaces where visitors can leave comments.
The Windows Live header link to someone's document folders on OneDrive.
A webpage link saved as a .url file in someone's "Favorites" folder on Windows OneDrive. Favorites can be created directly within OneDrive, or via the Windows Live Toolbar.

In Windows Live (primarily through profile), online actions, such as updating a status message, publishing photos, or updating profile info. These actions can take place on Windows Live or on other services someone has connected to their profile, such as Facebook or Twitter. These actions can show up as updates in feeds within Windows Live or on connected services.

The menu in Hotmail that includes actions a customer may take on the contents of the folder that is currently displayed. Some actions draw context from a selected message. For example, if someone selects a message, they can move all or delete all messages from that sender. If no message is selected, the actions occur at a folder level, such as marking all messages in the folder as read, or deleting all messages in the folder.
A semi-autonomous operating unit that is created to meet strategic business objectives.

An action taken on Windows Live or on partner websites such as Facebook that is considered to have social relevance and that might appear in an activity feed. For example, photo activity and status updates are considered to be socially relevant. Within Windows Live, friends see one another's relevant actions in feeds within Messenger, on Windows Live Home, and other places. Depending on the partner and their settings, actions that a customer takes on Windows Live may be visible on partner sites, actions they take on partner sites may be visible on Windows Live, or both.

An action taken on Windows Live or on partner websites such as Facebook that is considered to have social relevance and that might appear in an activity feed. For example, photo activity and status updates are considered to be socially relevant. Within Windows Live, friends see one another's relevant actions in feeds within Messenger, on Windows Live Home, and other places. Depending on the partner and their settings, actions that a customer takes on Windows Live may be visible on partner sites, actions they take on partner sites may be visible on Windows Live, or both.
The inventory quantities that are expected to be available at a future point in time calculated by adding scheduled supply to on-hand inventory and subtracting scheduled demand.
A schedule to produce a specific item and item quantity at a specific time and by specific human and operational resources.
A product family grouping that is used for forecast and demand scheduling.
A source document that documents the offer to buy products or the acceptance of an offer to sell products in exchange for payment.
The checkbox customers select to include their spaces blog in the updates that they share about themselves. This text links to Spaces.
The checkbox customers select to include their group discussions in the updates that they share about themselves. This text links to Groups.
Software or web service that provides an anonymous proxy designed to make user identity untraceable.
An instruction sent via mobile phone to perform a certain action on Windows Live, such as updating a status message, or to retrieve information, such as a list of the day's events).
The checkbox customers select to include their guestbook in the updates that they share about themselves. This text links to Spaces.
The checkbox customers select to include their lists in the updates that they share about themselves. This text links to Spaces.
The checkbox customers select to include changes to their friends in the updates that they share about themselves. This text links to Contacts.
The checkbox customers select to include notes left for them in the updates that they share about themselves. This text links to the notes webpage.
An email address that's attached to a mobile phone by a mobile provider and used for messaging transmitted over an email service.
The tooltip displayed when pointing to a personal folder icon on the Manage folders page on the Windows Live Devices website.

A website or service that a customer can connect in order to share what they've been doing on other websites, see their friends and their updates from other services in Windows Live, or share their Windows Live activity on other websites.
A folder someone using Windows Live Sync is synchronizing between computers.
The feature that allows users to navigate directly to the webpage of the top-ranked search result when a search is performed in the address bar.
The return to a customer's account of funds that were used to purchase an item. This may occur as a result of a customer's contacting a bank to dispute a credit-card transaction.
A client-server program accessed over a network that uses a web browser as the interface for the end user.
An action that restores the default factory settings of a device.
A folder that's automatically added to OneDrive when photos are uploaded from Windows Phone.
To sanction the future occurrence of an event in a system.
An itemized product that participates in an inventory process.
A record of the financial consequence an accounting event.
A source document that documents the offer to sell products or the acceptance of an offer to buy products in exchange for payment.
A geographic point or region.
The value of an economic resource that is quantified in monetary units and that is measured using an accounting valuation principle.
Persons who exist in no programmatic feature category, or more than one category.
A computer that a customer adds to their Windows Live account security information from which they can reset a forgotten password without providing further information.
The public multinational corporation that develops, manufactures, licenses, and supports a wide range of products and services predominantly related to computing.
The public multinational corporation that develops, manufactures, licenses, and supports a wide range of products and services predominantly related to computing.
Promotional newsletter sent to Windows Live customers containing feature tips and links to web content.
The label for the webpage where customers can access existing and create new online Office files using Office Web Apps.
A visual representation such as a picture, chart or table.
A service under which customers can acquire and redeem points for certain online services and digital products.
A process of repeated installation of a product, feature, tool, kit, pack, etc.
Pertaining to a request for payment.
A charge levied by a governing authority.
A fixed amount or percentage deducted from a quoted price or price total.
A quantity of currency that is offered or accepted to settle a past, present, or future obligation.
An operating-system installation and configuration that uses a virtual hard disk as the running operating system. There is no host operating system or hypervisor in a native-boot configuration.
The actual or potential ability of a resource to perform an activity or to produce output in a specified time period.
A time period division of a fiscal year.
A practice of reconciling a ledger account that represents a bank account by matching ledger account entries to bank statement entries.
The net value of an asset reported on a statement of financial position.
A discount that depends on prompt payment.
A source document that documents the receipt of cash or cash equivalents.
The authorization given by a payer to a payee, or by the institution with which the payer's account is held, consenting to the debiting of the payer's account.
An approximate 12-month fiscal period used by an organization that prepares annual financial statements.

A place to access a set of related content and experiences. A Hub brings together apps, services and content of the same theme. A Hub weaves apps, services and content together in a way that makes sense, so that everyday tasks are easier, with fewer steps.
A tablet-style portable computer that's designed for touch input and that lacks an integrated physical keyboard.
A report that documents the financial information and financial position of an organization.
The balance of an account at the beginning of a fiscal period.

A symmetric encryption key shared by two entities, such as between a user and the domain controller (DC), with a long lifetime. A password is a common example of a secret key. When used in a context that implies Kerberos only, a principal's secret key.
A tax levied by a government authority that is deducted from compensation.
A demonstration of a product or service that a customer interacts with to see how features work.
A demonstration of a product or service that a customer interacts with to see how features work.
A feature that enables customers to easily display two documents side by side, maximize a single document, and expand a window vertically by simply dragging window borders to the edge of the screen.
A setting that allows a user to turn off cellular, Wi-Fi, and Bluetooth on the phone simultaneously. Often required during takeoff and landing in an aircraft.
The actual software bits available to developers to enable them to use the Live Connect program.
A cost that is not directly attributed to the production of an item or the performance of a service.
A Microsoft sub-brand grouping digital-media products, including devices that play media, a software media player, and online media services.
A message that contains service-related content.
The standard long formats to display a date.
An Xbox Live online profile name.
The standard short formats to display a date. For example: MM/dd/yy; dd/MM/yy
A component of a hearing aid that is activated for use with a hearing aid compatible telephone.
A toggle switch that you tap to enter a SIM PIN.
A call made to an emergency number.
An authentication method that uses a proxy server.
A connection that enables the transfer of information using the 3G technology.
A feature that helps correct some common mistakes while dialing internationally or dialing while abroad.
To reply to an email, text message, or Calendar request by tapping the â€œrespondâ€ button.
A version of a product that can be used at no cost for a limited period of time for purposes of evaluation.
A version of a product that can be used at no cost for a limited period of time for purposes of evaluation.
A feature that lets you ring, lock, erase, or show your Windows phone on a map from account.microsoft.com.
The list of shortcuts to frequently-accessed websites.
The number used to send and receive messages.
A value-added tax (VAT) on products that is owed by the customer that receives the product, not by the vendor that delivers the product.
The collection title for musical artists that are in the top N% of sales/plays.
The main telephone number of a company. Not the same as an individualâ€™s work phone.
An Outlook contactâ€™s residential telephone number (usually a land line).
An Outlook contactâ€™s professional telephone number. Not a companyâ€™s main phone number.
A phone feature that enables speech recognition, pressing and holding the Start button.
Usually the spouse or domestic partner of a contact. Detail that can be added to a contactâ€™s profile, listed under "other."
A button that appears during an active phone call, allowing a user to add another person to his/her conference call.
A text string displayed in the status bar for Call Progress, alternating with the callee's name, to prompt the user that he/she can tap the bar to return to the call.
A text strings that appears in the status bar when the user can switch between the active call and the call on hold.
A text string displayed in the status bar during a held call, alternating with the held callee's name, to prompt the user that they can tap the bar to merge the calls.
A button that appears after the user takes a new Profile picture. Tap â€œretakeâ€ to delete the current picture and take another, or â€œacceptâ€ to upload it.
In Store, label for songs or videos whose content contains explicit sexuality, violence, or curse words.
The collection title for music albums that are in the top N% of sales/plays.
An icon tapped to initiate a voice conversation between two people.
A section of windowsphone.com containing procedural topics, videos, and links to support information about Windows Phone and related technologies.
A tile that updates dynamically to show content directly from the Start screen.
To post messages or upload photos to Facebook.
An icon visible in some screens of the phone, tapped to activate the Search function. Context-sensitive.
The computer-based program through which customers shop and download from the online Marketplace, play and manage music and video collections, and sync games, apps, and other media to their phones.
The Home screen of an unlocked Windows Phone.
The Home screen of an unlocked Windows Phone.
Logo assigned to the products that have passed Microsoft-designed tests for compatibility and reliability on Windows 7.
Logo assigned to the software products that have passed Microsoft designed tests for compatibility and reliability on Windows 7.
Logo assigned to the hardware products that have passed Microsoft designed tests for compatibility and reliability on Windows 7.
A program designed to identify compatible and reliable systems, software, and hardware products that have passed Microsoft-designed tests for compatibility and reliability on Windows 7.
A detection system that helps guard against intrusion attempts targeting known and newly discovered vulnerabilities in network protocols.
A program used to detect spyware and sometimes remove it.
To display an address or location on a map.
The time or times during the day that a child is restricted from using the computer.
The number of hours or minutes per day that a child is allowed to use the computer.
A program that shows details about a computer's hardware configuration, computer components, and software, including drivers.
A program that shows details about a computer's hardware configuration, computer components, and software, including drivers.
The UI label in Messenger for the aspect of the social view that displays unprioritized recent social activity of friends.
The UI label in Messenger for the aspect of the social view that displays unprioritized recent social activity of the user.

The infrastructure that manages low-level graphics-related tasks, such as output adapter and swap chain configuration, and provides a common framework for managing virtualized graphics components and resources.

The infrastructure that manages low-level graphics-related tasks, such as output adapter and swap chain configuration, and provides a common framework for managing virtualized graphics components and resources.
A continuous sequence of characters that share a common format.
A set of functions that are implemented by the operating system for use by drivers.

A certificate extension that contains information useful for verifying the trust status of a certificate, as defined by the 2008 Memo of the Network Working Group. This information potentially includes Uniform Resource Locations (URLs) where the issuing CAâ€™s certificate can be retrieved, as well as a location of an Online Certificate Status Protocol (OCSP) responder configured to provide status for the certificate in question.

A certificate extension that contains information useful for verifying the trust status of a certificate, as defined by the 2008 Memo of the Network Working Group. This information potentially includes Uniform Resource Locations (URLs) where the issuing CAâ€™s certificate can be retrieved, as well as a location of an Online Certificate Status Protocol (OCSP) responder configured to provide status for the certificate in question.
The basic software module for by smart cards that performs cryptography and includes algorithms for authentication, encoding, and encryption.

The API that supports PKI and X.509 certificates, such as certificate chain validation, certificate stores, and signature verification.
A certificate extension that indicates where the certificate revocation list for a CA can be retrieved. It can contain none, one, or many HTTP, file, or LDAP URLs.
A certificate extension that indicates where the certificate revocation list for a CA can be retrieved. It can contain none, one, or many HTTP, file, or LDAP URLs.
In a public key infrastructure hierarchy, the certification authority that that issues certificates to users and computers.
In a public key infrastructure hierarchy, the certification authority that that issues certificates to users and computers.

A protocol that allows real-time validation of a certificateâ€™s status by having the CryptoAPI make a call to an OCSP responder and the OCSP responder providing an immediate validation of the revocation status for the presented certificate. Typically, an OCSP responder responds with the revocation status check request based on the certificate revocation list (CRL) or other forms of revocation status it retrieves from the certification authorities.

A protocol that allows real-time validation of a certificateâ€™s status by having the CryptoAPI make a call to an OCSP responder and the OCSP responder providing an immediate validation of the revocation status for the presented certificate. Typically, an OCSP responder responds with the revocation status check request based on the certificate revocation list (CRL) or other forms of revocation status it retrieves from the certification authorities.
A configuration mode for the Certificate Enrollment Web Service in which it will only process renewal requests.
A hexadecimal string that contains the SHA-1 hash of the certificate.

In Server Manager and Event Viewer, the urgency of an event or error condition, system fault, failure, or action by either the system or the user. Severity can be any of four industry-standard values: Information, Warning, Error, or Critical. These values are defined in the Event Viewer Help.

In Windows PowerShell, a script that runs when Windows PowerShell or Windows PowerShell Integrated Scripting Environment (ISE) starts. The profile script sets up and customizes the Windows PowerShell environment and can contain cmdlets, scripts, functions, or any valid Windows PowerShell command.
A process that builds one or more certificate paths. The certificate paths may or may not trace up to a self-signed or root certificate.

A certificate extension used by the certificate chaining engine to determine what certificate was used to sign a presented certificate. The AKI can contain the issuer name, serial number, public key information, or no information at all. By matching the information in a certificateâ€™s AKI extension to a CA certificateâ€™s Subject Key Identifier (SKI) extension, a certificate chain can be built.

A certificate extension used by the certificate chaining engine to determine what certificate was used to sign a presented certificate. The AKI can contain the issuer name, serial number, public key information, or no information at all. By matching the information in a certificateâ€™s AKI extension to a CA certificateâ€™s Subject Key Identifier (SKI) extension, a certificate chain can be built.
A content of a kit item that may consist of one or more components (that are raw materials, regular sellable items, or kit items), resources, and text comments.
A pick where the quantity handled is higher than the required quantity of the source document.

An entity that is responsible for deducting the money from the customer credit card account and moving the money to or from the merchant's account. The user of the payment service will have to sign up with one or more payment providers.

The bin at a dedicated area that contains items or components that are replenished manually. The items are included on component lists like a production BOM for obtaining an exact registration for cost and invoicing purposes, but they are not important or common enough to include on pick lines.

The sound alerts, alerts on screen (text), and badges that are pushed by applications to a device. For the Windows Phone, push notifications are available through the Lync Server Push Notification Service. For the iPhone, iPad, and iPod touch devices, notifications are available through the Apple Push Notification Service.
A feature to manage the creation of sellable items from other sellable items using nonproduction resources.
A group of inventoriable items to be sold as a new item.
A supply order that represents a request to fulfill demand for an assembly item by picking items on the assembly BOM or modified on the order and assembling them.

An offset value that changes the due date of any assembly order component that belongs to the assembly BOM during replenishment planning. The assembly line due date is then calculated as Due Date = Starting Date - Lead-Time Offset.
The act of taking apart components, resources, or items.
The location where items are placed for internal operations.
The stage bin where picked components are placed before consumption.
The process that warehouse employees follow to move items from one bin to another bin without using a source document.
Transfer an amount from the merchant's account back to the customer's account. The amount can be full or partial.
A cost that can be directly allocated to a cost object, such as a material purchase for a specific product.
A variable cost that can change dramatically because it involves large purchases or expenditures that cannot be spread out over time.
A subscription service that includes various online services, such as security, productivity, and educational features.
Software that enables management of Hotmail email, calendar, and contacts from within Outlook.
Someone with whom a user has established a mutual social relationship on a third-party service that refers to such a relationship as a connection.
A user presence state of being unavailable.
A user presence state of being unavailable.
A list of apps and websites of any type that a parent chooses which a child can use at any time and for as long as necessary outside of curfew hours.
An app chosen by a parent that a child can use at any time and for as long as necessary outside of curfew hours.
A website that a child has permission to use anytime outside of curfew hours.
An instant message or text message conversation between two or more participants.
A statement that a device makes to indicate that it can be trusted to access secure resources, such a folder on a file share.

The program that enables developers to connect to Live and easily use Microsoft account, OneDrive, Hotmail, and Messenger within their apps, websites, and devices. Live Connect provides a set of standards-based APIs and the downloadable Live SDK.
A nonfinal release of Windows that's made available to developers.

A statement indicating that the copyright holder reserves, or holds for their own use, all the rights provided by copyright law, such as distribution, performance, and creation of derivative works; that is, they have not waived any such right.
A brief musical composition.
A mobile broadband or other network or data plan that bills according to data use, such as megabytes downloaded, messages sent, or webpages viewed.
A person or business that makes data or applications available to customers through an online market.
A networking feature that lets one computer directly place information into the memory of another computer.
A networking feature that lets one computer directly place information into the memory of another computer.
A storage pool that exposes physical disks that are currently available for inclusion in a storage pool on a particular storage subsystem.
The layout and general resiliency of data across multiple disks in a virtual disk or storage space.
The layout and general resiliency of data across multiple disks in a virtual disk or storage space.
Pertaining to the resiliency type for a volume that stripes data across physical disks with no resiliency in a Microsoft Storage Spaces storage pool.
A volume that duplicates data across two or three physical disks in a Microsoft Storage Spaces storage pool.
Pertaining to the resiliency type for a volume that stripes data and parity information across physical disks in a Microsoft Storage Spaces storage pool.
A collection of one or more physical disks from a previously created storage pool.
A method of starting the computer that speeds boot time by ending the user session and hibernating the computer, rather than shutting down all running services.

A small amount of executable code contained in the master boot record that scans the partition table for the active partition, finds the starting sector of the active partition, loads a copy of the boot sector from the active partition into memory, and transfers control to the executable code in the boot sector.
A runtime environment for Windows Store apps that's designed to minimize app impact on the computer by placing runtime restrictions on what apps can do.
A filtering feature that monitors downloaded apps for malware or unknown reputation.
A feature of Windows that includes a set of maintenance tasks that run automatically when the user's PC is idle.
A feature of BitLocker that enables IT pros to encrypt a disk before a user begins to use it.
A BitLocker extension that adds management capabilities to BitLocker.
A feature of BitLocker that allows unlocking of an OS volume using a key received over the network.
The Hyper-V technology that runs on the Windows Client operating system, rather than Windows Server.
The ability for IT pros to define how users access a system based on dynamic qualities, such as a user's location or role.
A Windows feature designed to help users avoid data loss by automatically saving versions of files and copies of deleted files so that users can recover them.
A single set of sign-in credentials (email address and password) that provides user access to PCs running Windows and Live-connected services.
A technology that allows for the installation and use of multiple user-interface languages.
A UI element that enables users to locate and select files.
The activation of systems in an enterprise environment by using an established Active Directory implementation and the same key types.
A message or other indicator that informs users of events that are unrelated to their current activity, such as the number of new messages received while their computer is locked.
A transient message that contains relevant, time-sensitive information and that provides quick access to the subject of that content in an app.
A certification program to ensure that devices, systems, and apps are compatible, reliable, and can perform to meet Windows standards.
Tools and documentation to certify apps for Windows.
The test automation framework used to certify devices or systems for Windows.
The test automation framework used to certify devices or systems for Windows.
The test automation framework used to certify devices or systems for Windows.
The ability to easily return a PC to a prior state, either by reinstalling Windows and keeping their files or by resetting the PC to the original factory state.
A customized process that identifies and fixes potential problems during PC startup.
The ability for some devices to act like physical smart cards even if they aren't.
The process of activating Windows.
To place at least two fingers on an object and rotate your fingers in a clockwise or counterclockwise direction.
A gesture represented by placing at least two fingers on an object and rotating your fingers in a clockwise or counterclockwise direction.
A gesture represented by placing at least two fingers on an object and rotating your fingers in a clockwise or counterclockwise direction.
The ActiveX control that facilitates video calling in Hotmail.
A relational data store that's included in Windows and is used by several Windows Services.
A relational data store that's included in Windows and is used by several Windows Services.
A feature that assembles a composite photo collage from multiple source photos.
A process that verifies and eliminates lengthy chkdsk due to any transient errors that NTFS detects.
The process of reducing the number of slabs allocated in thinly provisioned arrays and thinly provisioned virtual disks by rearranging data from sparsely populated slabs to densely populated slabs.
A feature in Windows that communicates with a Microsoft online service to determine a PC's approximate location based on wireless network or IP address info.

The collection of hardware and software that enables the five essential characteristics (on-demand self-service, broad network access, resource pooling, rapid elasticity, and measured service) of cloud computing. The cloud infrastructure can be viewed as containing both a physical layer and an abstraction layer. The physical layer consists of the hardware resources that are necessary to support the cloud services being provided, and typically includes server, storage and network components. The abstraction layer consists of the software deployed across the physical layer, which manifests the essential cloud characteristics. Conceptually the abstraction layer sits above the physical layer.

The cloud infrastructure provisioned for exclusive use by a single organization comprising multiple consumers (e.g., business units). It may be owned, managed, and operated by the organization, a third party, or some combination of them, and it may exist on or off premises.

The cloud infrastructure that is provisioned for open use by the general public. It may be owned, managed, and operated by a business, academic, or government organization, or some combination of them. It exists on the premises of the cloud provider.

The cloud infrastructure is a composition of two or more distinct cloud infrastructures (private, community, or public) that remain unique entities, but are bound together by standardized or proprietary technology that enables data and application portability (e.g., cloud bursting for load balancing between clouds).

The capability provided to the consumer for using the providerâ€™s applications running on a cloud infrastructure. The applications are accessible from various client devices through either a thin client interface, such as a web browser (e.g., web-based email), or a program interface. The consumer does not manage or control the underlying cloud infrastructure, including network, servers, operating systems, storage, or even individual application capabilities, with the possible exception of limited user-specific application configuration settings.

The capability provided to the consumer for using the providerâ€™s applications running on a cloud infrastructure. The applications are accessible from various client devices through either a thin client interface, such as a web browser (e.g., web-based email), or a program interface. The consumer does not manage or control the underlying cloud infrastructure, including network, servers, operating systems, storage, or even individual application capabilities, with the possible exception of limited user-specific application configuration settings.

The capability provided to the consumer of provisioning processing, storage, networks, and other fundamental computing resources where the consumer is able to deploy and run arbitrary software, which can include operating systems and applications. The consumer does not manage or control the underlying cloud infrastructure but has control over operating systems, storage, and deployed application, and possibly has limited control of select networking components (e.g., host firewalls).

The capability provided to the consumer of provisioning processing, storage, networks, and other fundamental computing resources where the consumer is able to deploy and run arbitrary software, which can include operating systems and applications. The consumer does not manage or control the underlying cloud infrastructure but has control over operating systems, storage, and deployed application, and possibly has limited control of select networking components (e.g., host firewalls).

A user account and associated credentials that is used to access Microsoftâ€™s and 3rd partiesâ€™ business services, such as Office 365. Work or school accounts are usually assigned to end users by their organization (work, school, non-profit) and managed by the admin. However, some business services like Yammer support work or school accounts that were created by end users, without IT involvement. We sometimes refer to these accounts as â€œviralâ€ AAD accounts but we donâ€™t use this term externally. Work or school accounts are stored in Azure Active Directory (AAD) and managed by Microsoft on behalf of the organization. One of the key difference with a Microsoft account is that users donâ€™t own the account and will typically loose access to it if they leave the organization. Other aspects like password policies are imposed by admins.
